results.creator_credit: Francis Jupurrula Kelly and Thomas Rice
results.credit_line: Produced by Rebel Films and commissioned by ACMI
results.material_description: Steel, aluminium, plastic, Mulga branch, fencing wire, automotive paint, acrylic paint

constellations_primary.name: Culture and identity on the Australian screen
constellations_primary.description: Australian screen culture is distinctive, unexpected, playful and serious when it matters. Indigenous productions make a huge contribution to the unique identity of the Australian moving image.

results.description:
David Batty and Francis Jupurrurla Kelly’s Bush Mechanics (2001) only ran for one season, but it became a cult classic and spawned short films, museum exhibitions and even a videogame. This Warlpiri-language miniseries owes its popularity to its distinctive cultural world of Warlpiri humour, music and experience, where nyurulypa (good tricks) are used to keep wrecked cars on the red-sand roads of outback Australia. The cast use mulga wood, spinifex and clever hacks to showcase their ingenious approach to mechanics.

Demonstrating this winning combination of Warlpiri and car culture, Ngapa Jukuurpa (Water Dreaming) is painted on an old Ford ZF Fairlane in the series’ final episode. The Bush Mechanics drive the ‘Ngapa car’ to Broome to trade for pearl shells to use in a ceremony to break the drought.

results.title: Alt-Right Arabesque
results.credit_line:
Baiden Pailthorpe
Single-channel video, 3 mins.
ACMI Collection
results.material_description: Single channel video, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
Alt-Right Arabesque continues Pailthorpe’s interest in the performing digital body, yet with a new focus on the aesthetics of the resurgent and re-branded fascism (the so-called Alt-right). The sickly-looking protagonist in this work symbolises the infamous 4chan moderator or frequent Reddit user, who spectacularly twirls en arabesque in box-fresh Nike Airmax. A variety of surreal political imagery, visual references and cinematic techniques long associated with fascism and propaganda in the history of cinema are combined in this animation to create a strange and intense response to the overwhelming weirdness of 2016.
[Source: https://sydneycontemporary.com.au/video17/
Last accessed 2/9/2020]

results.title: [Unidentified 16mm Film]

video_links.name: Uncredited footage, circa 1945, performances and parade.

results.brief_description: Film contains silent footage of various vaudeville and circus-style performances including dancing, acrobatics, slapstick comedy and more. The film also includes extensive footage of the British Navy marching in a street parade in Melbourne. One shot appears to be Elizabeth Street, featuring trams and the Flinders Street Station clocktower.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 26]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur cinematographer and filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film is situated in the Victorian Alpine Region in the summer months when the only snows are at the very top of the mountains. Wallace focuses on the roads that wind, at times dramatically, through the mountain range as well as the surrounding landscape of trees, rocks and waterways.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’, ‘The Victorian Alps’
00:00:50:00 views from the road and a small old house
00:01:06:00 sign ‘Alpine Road’ with lots of information for the traveller
00:01:25:00 sign ‘You are now entering Mount Hotham Alpine Reserve’
00:01:35:00 looking across a corner of a dirt road high up in the mountains
00:02:22:00 roads, signs and aerials on top of the mountains and a melting snowman
00:02:58:00 brass sundial
00:04:46:00 sign warning to ‘keep to the left of the poles’ and directional sign to ‘Hotham, Diamentina, Harrietville’
00:05:20:00 chair lift pulley station and 1970s style four wheel drive vehicle, a chalet and hamlet
00:05:55:00 a small A-frame chalet or hut
00:06:30:00 views of roads, trees and cars with the mountains in the background
00:07:05:00 two purple swamp hens (common to wetlands or rivers of Eastern Australia)
00:07:50:00 signs ‘Mount Buffalo’ and ‘Eurobin Falls’ followed by views of cascading waters over rocky embankments and cliffs
00:08:30:00 sign ‘Mackeys Lookout’ followed by views out over the valleys below including cars negotiating the tight turns on the roads winding down the mountain
00:09:08:00 sign ‘Rollarson’s Falls’
00:09:35:00 hikers negotiate logs and rocks along the path
00:10:16:00 a long narrow waterfall into a lovely natural rock pool
00:11:00:00 looking out over misty valleys through an old walk bridge
00:13:08:00 a narrow waterfall in a rocky cliffface
00:13:36:00 snow along the sides of the road
00:14:26:00 sign ‘Toownag Gap, Mt Buffalo, Mt Bogong’ and a visitor looking through binoculars from a lookout
00:14:46:00 looking down from a higher vantage spot on a long windy road through the mountains toward a township beyond
00:15:20:00 views of electricity towers across the ranges
00:15:50:00 sign ‘Pretty Valley Branch East Kiewa River’
00:16:11:00 sign ‘rocky Valley Dam’ and scenes around the dam
00:17:05:00 sign ‘Strawberry Saddle’ followed by a mob of emus
00:18:07:00 sign ‘Bundara River’ in the Victorian Alpine Region
00:19:50:00 sign ‘Omeo’, Victoria, followed by an older style cattle truck travelling along a street and the Public Telegraph Office in the township

results.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.creator_credit: Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja
results.credit_line:
Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Script: Courtney Collins with Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja

Sound: Left of Elephant Sound

Single-channel video

Approx. 5 mins

Commissioned by ACMI and Artbank
results.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the centre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

constellations_primary.name: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
constellations_primary.description: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls explores the reality of living in Mparntwe (Alice Springs) through the eyes of the artists, who grew up there. Place and Indigenous representation are also vital to the other works in this Constellation.

English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the cetnre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

results.title: Emulation of Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific for DOS
results.brief_description:
Carriers at War 1941-1945: Fleet Carrier Operations in the Pacific is a war simulation game. In the game, the player takes on the role of the task force commander in the Pacific Theater during World War II. The player can play as both the U.S. and the Japanese Empire in scenarios such as Pearl Harbor, Coral Sea, Midway, Eastern Solomons, Santa Cruz and Philippine Sea. The game is played on a 72x84 hexagonal grid on which different units and squadrons, such as naval vessels and land based aircraft, are positioned. The player chooses actions for these units, the consequences for which are simulated by the computer. The game is quasi real-time, meaning that the game can be paused at any given moment at which time the player can give orders to the units. All interaction with the game is through a menu interface. Orders that can be given to units include strike, escort, transport, support, refuel and more complex maneuvers such as strike routines.

Source: Play It Again website:
http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/goldfields/

Last accessed: 6/05/2021

Original game developed by Strategic Studies Group for Commodore 64, published in 1984 by Strategic Studies Group
